explanation:
To determine whether OS_FileOpen_Impl calls itself (directly or indirectly) the analyser must inspect every function or macro invoked by the target and any code the macros expand to:

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Called directly by OS_FileOpen_Impl (per static call graph). Must be examined to see if it (or any function it calls) can lead back to OS_FileOpen_Impl.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain the impl record; the macro expansion could contain function calls or indirect calls not obvious from the source text. The analyser needs the macro definition/expansion to discover any hidden callees.
- OS_impl_filehandle_table: The table identifier used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its type/definition could affect the macro expansion or index logic (e.g. if the macro invokes helper functions) and thus must be checked for indirect calls.
- open: POSIX call used to open the file. Although unlikely to call back into the OS layer, it must be verified (or assumed safe) to rule out an indirect path to OS_FileOpen_Impl.
- strerror: Called when open fails. Must be checked to ensure it does not call into application/OS functions that could eventually invoke OS_FileOpen_Impl.
- OS_DEBUG: Logging macro/function used on error. It may expand to other OS logging functions (e.g. OS_printf) that could, in theory, invoke code paths back to OS_FileOpen_Impl; therefore its definition/implementation must be inspected.

Only by inspecting these symbols (and any functions they call transitively) can an analyser reliably conclude whether there is any direct or indirect recursion involving OS_FileOpen_Impl.
